question: Hey! Other partygoers turn and look. So does Tuck. His eyes blaze. He storms over.
Tuck!...
He stole my tape recorder.
I told you I worked for a newspaper.
answer: This is a cocktail party, not a damn news conference!

question: Well... he's right. I'm drunk. Guess I owe these folks an apology, Lydia. She puts her hand on his arm.
answer: It's okay, Tuck. Forget it. Tuck pulls away from her.

question: Not until I apologize to these people! We got some real famous, all- American hero-types with us tonight! Space-walkers, an' moon- walkers... an' Earth-orbiters! It's obvious who Tuck is talking about. They stand there in their crisp uniforms, with short hair, erect postures and disapproving expressions. Gentlemen... ... I'm sorry... You boys have all gone up in these babies. Hats off to you. I envy you fellas... ... The most excitement I ever had was the time I landed a crippled F-14 on the deck of a rocking flattop in zero visibility with the nose gear -- Tuck sees RUSTY, one of the ex-astronauts in the crowd, turn away in disgust. -- Don't turn your back on me, Rusty... ... At least when my moment of truth came, I didn't take a dump down the leg of my flightsuit... if that rings any bells for you! Rusty looks enraged. He advances toward Tuck. But Tuck stands his ground -- smiles -- and drops Rusty with a hooking right fist. Uproar! TWO young MARINES rush up to Tuck. Only two of you?
answer: Oh, Tuck... are you all right? Tuck gives her a dazed expression. No one else offers assistance. They look upon Tuck as a complete disgrace.

question: Write a letter to your congressman! Lydia marches off, reclaims Tuck who waits for her on tottering legs, and heads for the door. And you said you weren't coming * tonight! *
answer: No. I said I wasn't invited. Don't give me that look.

question: What look?
answer: That 'Poor Pitiful Tuck' look. I had a great time tonight. I like getting drunk. I enjoy being hit in the face. Lydia rolls her eyes at Tuck's hopelessness. Tuck picks up the tape recorder from the car seat. What's on this, anyway?

question: I'm working on a story.
It's a good story. Not that you'll ever know, of course. You never read any of my articles.
answer: That's not so. I read the one about me.

question: I think you only looked at the pictures.
answer: Well, you gotta admit, those were great pictures. Maybe I should grow that mustache back. Okay. Tell me about the story.

question: Espionage in Silicon Valley. The buying and selling of advanced technological secrets.
That's why I had my tape recorder with me. Every high-tech company on the West Coast was represented at that party tonight.
answer: Well, you're right about one thing, Lydia... ... I ain't gonna read it.

question: What's this?
answer: Nothing. Just some homework I'm doing. Tuck takes it from her hand and puts it down. How about a drink?

question: I can't stay, Tuck.
answer: Just for a minute. I know what you'd like

question: No, Tuck. I --
answer: What's tea come in again? A can? A jar? Wait... I remember. Little bags, right? Yeah... here they are.

question: I'm not staying, Tuck. Tuck can see she means it. His expression turns serious.
answer: Don't go, Lydia. Please stay. He puts his arms around her.

question: Tuck --
answer: Mmmm. I love your perfume. What's it called again?

question: I don't wear perfume.
answer: C'mon. What's it called again?... He's breaking down her resistance.

question: Midnight Lace.
answer: Mmmmm. Smells so good. Don't go, Lydia... Lydia?... Lydia! Owwww!! Lydia! Wait! Tuck rushes up to the car window. Where you going?!

question: I'm leaving, Tuck. Don't try to stop me. Our relationship has no future, and you know it. You drink too much. You fight too much. You don't value anything. You destroy everything that's good in your life. You ruin it. You throw it away. And if I stayed any longer, I'd be next.

... Feels like it starts about here, then swoops around and comes up to here, then -- zoom! -- heads back down to about here, and that's when I start to feel nauseous and... Greenbush tries unsuccessfully to stifle a yawn. Am I boring you?
Because if I'm boring you, just tell me. You're not the only internist in the phone book, you know.
answer: Jack, please! Let's not have a falling out. Your monthly office visit is the cornerstone of my entire medical practice. Anything besides the nausea?

question: Headaches. Big, pounding headaches. Lots of pain.
Yeah. The dream.
Want to hear it?

I'm at work. I'm at the market. I'm working one of the registers. The next customer is this lady with bright orange hair, Mrs. Mulrooney. She's a * regular. She's wearing those pointy -- * you know -- Harlequin Sunglasses. With little sparkly things in them. And a lime green jumpsuit with a three-inch wide red vinyl belt.

Yeah. I have the same dream every night. Anyway, I'm passing her stuff over the bar-code scanner, and I don't notice it, but the computer's gone nuts, and it's ringing up all the wrong prices. I mean, twelve-hundred dollars for a can of coffee! So when I'm all done, I look at the register and the total's like way over a hundred thousand dollars. So Mrs. Mulrooney says to me, real * calm, 'I don't carry that kind of money on me, sweetie, will you take this instead'... ... And she reaches down into her purse and comes out with a 357 Magnum this long and shoves the barrel into my face and pulls back on the trigger -- and that's when I wake up screaming!...
Yeah. What do you think?
answer: I won't think anything until we run the usual tests. Slip out of those clothes, would you? You're fine, Jack. I can't find anything wrong with you. Jack looks disappointed.

question: What?...
answer: Everything checks out. Jack can't believe his ears. He seems ready to demand his money back. You are under a lot of stress, however. You're way too uptight, Jack.

question: Uptight? Are you sure that's the correct medical term?
answer: Look -- do you have any vacation time coming? You need a rest. Get away for some R & R. Peace and Quiet -- that's my prescription for you.

question: I'm fine. Do you have any aspirin on you? We had a date last night, you know?
Our date. Last night.
You forgot? How could you forget?
answer: Look, Jack, I told you already, if you're gonna be a part of my life, you can't hassle me about stuff. Jack gives her a long, baffled look.

question: Great place to have a meeting.
answer: Good as any. Do these bananas look ripe to you?

question: Let's get to the point, all right?
The satellite missile guidance system.
answer: Uh... we haven't perfected that just yet. We got a bit sidetracked. Blanchard draws back apprehensively.

question: What are you talking about?
answer: I'm talking about the world in an eyedropper. Miniaturization. We can shrink anything. Right down to the size of -- -- a pea. Even smaller than that.

question: Bullshit.
answer: We brought in Ozzie Wexler. The name draws a blank with Blanchard. The man who invented Action Man, the 3-D video game.

question: Action Man didn't work!
answer: Yes it did. The bottom dropped out of the video market, that's all. The public never gave it a chance. Blanchard seems totally exasperated and pissed off. Come and see for yourself what we've done.

question: Don't pan anywhere! Keep the camera on me. Miniaturization is achieved through the pairing of two 5000- Series Photon Echo Memroy Chips... called 'PEMS' for short. The two chips are intergrated, but electronically opposed. Only one is necessary for miniaturization, but both are required for re-enlargement. Keep rolling. I want a record of everything. Nervous? Do you really need that? Tuck removes a flask from his pocket -- pauses to con- sider it -- then pours its contents down the sink.
answer: Okay? Ozzie nods his head, but then sees Tuck return the flask to his pocket.

question: You're taking it anyway?
answer: I have to. It's my lucky flask.

question: Okay. Now remember -- trust your on-board computer. Use it. I know you've studied, but don't rely on yourself when you don't have to. The computer's been programmed to answer any question you might have.
Maybe we should review our objects one more time.
answer: I know what our objectives are. Retrieve tissue samples and test efficiency of surgical laser beam. Look, Oz... I know I'm no prize, but I'm the only one you could get. And this mission's the only one I could get. So let's just get the job done.

question: The game works! It's not my fault the public lost interest in video! Good luck, Captain.
answer: Just get me home again before my air runs out.

question: Don't worry. You've got a 24-hour supply. That's just too bad. Do you read me, Captain?
Zero minus three.
PEM Number One functional.
PEM Number Two functional.
... Fun, romance, excitement, relaxation --
It's a cruise -- you get them all.
Ah, but you're a single young man. What about romance?
answer: As long as it isn't too exciting.

question: Great! No radio. No communication. I'm completely cut off. If only I could see out. Hmmm... maybe I can. Oz said this thing can answer any question I have... ... Hey, you... can I see out through the eyes of this beast?
Huh??
answer: We can patch into the optic nerve. Intercept the electrical impulses going to the brain.

question: Great. How do I find it?
Yeah.
answer: Say... didn't you prepare for this mission?

question: Do I have to defend myself to a machine!? Let's have the directions!
answer: Okay, okay. Keep your eye on the screen, Player Number One, begin the first level... and good luck!

question: Swell! It's built out of old video games.
answer: Take radial artery to axillary artery to internal jugular vein to frontal sinus to...

question: Hello. Can you hear me? Jack turns toward the Boys, sees that they are occupied in their task. He shrugs it off. Respond if you can hear me.
It works. I can hear you. Jack turns fast toward the Boys.
This is no joke. Jack looks startled. The voice is not coming from the Boys at all. He turns back toward the Attendant.
I'm not out there. I'm in here!
In you. In your body! They put me in you instead of the rabbit. Why'd they do that?
answer: Yes, of course. However, I've apparently just gone insane!! He jumps back into his car and SQUEALS away.

question: Hey, pal... how come I get the sinking feeling that you don't know what's going on any more than I do?
answer: A little voice inside your ear, huh? Okay, Jack, let's just have a look and see... Greenbush raises his ear-exam flashlight to Jack's ear.

question: Oh, God!!
answer: Didn't see a thing, Jack. Why don't you just go home and try to get some rest.

question: Where are you!? Who are you!?
answer: Jack, we've got ourselves a little situation here.

question: You know my name!
answer: I heard somebody call you that... right before the lights went out, so to speak. Jack rubs his temples.

question: It even sees what I'm doing!
I'm going to sleep for a little while. Not long. Say, two or three days. And when I wake up, if you're not gone --
Voice? Are you still there?
answer: You jerk! Are you trying to kill us both!? How many of those pills did you take, anyway!?

question: Oh, no! It's back.
I'm not listening to you.
answer: Jack! Please! Jack begins to HUM to himself to cover Tuck's voice. Jack! We have to talk!

question: I think I'll watch some TV!
I am real, Jack. You do believe that now, don't you?
Believe it, Jack, because it's true. Did you ever see that movie where Tony Curtis and Sidney Poitier are handcuffed together?
Well, that's us, Jack.
We're in this together and we have to help each other. You don't work at the lab, do you?
And you don't know anything about the experiment, do you?
We're late. We've missed the best part of the experiment.
answer: Relax, would ya? By the way -- who's your guy?

question: Huh?
answer: Your pilot? Your guy inside the * pod? *

question: Oh. Somebody you know, I think. Captain Tuck Pendelton.
Yeah. What's wrong?
answer: Oh, nothing. Except Tuck Pendelton's got the worst attitude problem in military history. He's been drummed out of every space program since Gemini -- and he drinks like a fish. However... the dumb sonofabitch did save my life once. Niles gives Blanchard a look. He pulled me out of my space capsule when it caught fire on the pad. Of course the only reason he got to me so fast was because he had sneaked into a restricted area where he wasn't allowed.

question: There's two chips! It's a dual chip system!
answer: We have one. Where's the other?

question: In the Pod.
answer: But, where's the Pod?? The Pod's in him. Canker looks at the photo of Jack, then turns to Igoe.

question: ... We've got to keep our hands clean. This is your baby... you change the dirty diapers.
What about him?
Pendelton's been around the military long enough to know that every mission contains an element of risk.
Well?
answer: Blanchard's stone-walling. He knows more than he's telling.

question: Guess who's arriving at the airport in exactly four hours?
You got it. Lydia smiles knowingly, glances back at the Vector-Scope Lab, then turns to face Duane again.
answer: The pieces are beginning to fall into place.

question: You know... that isn't much time.
answer: Gosh, you're right! Why didn't I think of that?

question: I mean, what happens if we fail? What happens if we don't get this chip back and your air supply runs out? What happens then?! TUCK'S VOICE * Then you've got a miniaturized * submersible pod floating around * your insides with a tiny, little * human skeleton at the helm. * Aaagghh!
answer: Not a pretty thought, is it?

question: Mr. Jack Putter?
From World Tour Travel. Cruise tickets, I think. Sign on number twelve. Mind if I use your phone? Gotta call my dispatcher.
Shot out your TV, huh, man? Just like Elvis. Lucky man. Goin' on a cruise. What about your roommate?
Thought I heard you talkin' to somebody as I came to the door.
Run!
Go to a pay phone. Call a cab.
answer: Where am I going? How am I gonna pay for it?

question: You're going to my place. You can pay the cabbie when you get there... my treat.
I heard that... and you're right. I could use a drink, Jack. Bet you could, too.
Well, I do. See if there's a bottle of Cutty under the sofa * cushion, would ya? Jack makes a face, but takes a look. No! The other cushion.
Got it.
How...?
answer: Let me worry about that. Okay, Jack -- down the hatch.

question: I'm not much of a drinker.
answer: C'mon! Let 'er rip! Then Hmmm. Smells a little strange. Looks a shade green. Oh, well. Probably just some harmless biochemical waste material... ... mixed with a bit of stomach acid. What the hell! Rot-gut whiskey's better than none at all. Cheers! Wow! That's strong enough to grow hair on a snake! Nuthin' like a little Cutty and Sam Cooke to chase away the miseries of the day. Jack! Hey, Jack! Jack!

question: What?...
Why?
answer: Because I just realized I don't know what you look like. Hey, you're not drunk, are you?

question: No. Just a little dizzy.
answer: Ha! And after only one stinking drink!

question: Didn't you just save my life?
You warned me about that phony messenger.
answer: Well, yeah. I guess I did, but --

question: But let's face it... We need help. Can you drive? Is your head clear?
Slap yourself in the face.
In the face. Slap yourself. Wack! Jack does. Harder. Wack! Jack does it harder. Again. Wack! Jack does it again. How's that feel?
answer: One more time! Wack! Jack does it one more time.

question: Okay! How's that feel now?
Who are those men?
answer: Bad guys! Very bad guys! The Black Sedan also comes to a stop -- about ten cars back. I don't see 'em. I think we gave 'em the slip! ... you might say Tuck's been taken hostage.

question: Who has him?
answer: That's a little hard to explain. We need something called a 'PEM' to get him back. It's a micro- chip. It was taken from the Vector-Scope lab this morning.

question: Vector-Scope! Everything's comin' up Vector-Scope today. Have you gone to the police?
answer: There's no time for long explanations and police reports. As a matter of fact, we only have...

question: Sixteen hours.
answer: Sixteen hours?! Can't we negotiate for more time?

question: Not a chance.
I gotta pee real bad! I can't believe I said that! You didn't tell me she was going * to be so beautiful.
Absolutely. And I think we should tell her the truth, too.
answer: Who would believe it? Besides... it's humiliating being this small. There -- I've said it!

question: What's so bad about being small? The Customer now comes up behind Jack.
Never mind. Jack flushes the urinal -- watches the water swirl down the drain. You still there?
Jack! Jack! Are you all right? What happened? Seems like we experienced a massive power surge. Hey, Jack... you there, babe? What's goin' on, Jack!? Your heart rate's slowin' way down!
Jack! You had me worried. Thought I'd lost you for a minute, kid. What happened? Where's Lydia? Where are we? I can't see a thing. Why's it so dark?
You're what?? Can't make you out, Jack. Message garbled. Try again.
Dr. Canker! Get in here! Well?
Do we need him alive? Jack's eyes widen at this.
answer: Oh, yes. He should be alive.

question: Bring a blanket!
answer: I know how to warm him up...

question: Maybe everything. The Cowboy deals in stolen technology. He's a middleman. Why do you think he arrived today? Dollars to donuts he leads us right to that chip. The Cowboy gets on a pay phone. I'd love to know who he's calling.
Very funny.
He's fifty feet away.
answer: Let me try... He's leaving a message for somebody... Victor Scrimshaw. Hey! That was the guy in the truck!

question: I don't believe this.
answer: He's staying at the Mark Hopkins Hotel. He wants Scrimshaw to pick him up at six in the morning...

question: Six in the morning?
You're amazing.
Let's go. As they walk briskly off:
He's very mysterious -- and very powerful. I can call the paper for his file when we get there.
The Mark Hopkins Hotel.
answer: This place looks like a Ferrari owner's convention!

question: Get the suitcase from the trunk.
I'm checking in. It's less suspicious if I have a suitcase.
answer: How'd you know this was here?

question: Margaret! I'm meeting with the Cowboy tomorrow morning and I still don't have that other chip!
-- We had him! He slipped right through our fingers! I'm thinking maybe your boy Igoe's not all he's cracked up to be, Margaret! Canker's eyes begin to blaze.
answer: You're crazy! He's the most perfect creature on earth.

question: Just find that idiot supermarket clerk -- and don't let the Cowboy out of your sight, either! Igoe takes the phone from Canker's hands and hangs it up. She turns and throws open his robe revealing a tattoo on his chest.
answer: Come to Momma. He embraces her passionately.

question: You're awfully eager, aren't you?
answer: You bet. I'm into this now. I'm hooked on adventure. What's your plan?

question: Okay. The Cowboy will lead us to the chip, right?
Me.
answer: Sure. And when Scrimshaw's men come by to pick up the Cowboy, they're gonna get you and me instead.

question: Yeah... but I don't look like the Cowboy.
I don't know, Jack. It's a good plan, but it seems dangerous. Victor Scrimshaw likes to play hardball.
Well... neither am I. I've never run from danger in my life.
I'm not going to... ... but are you sure you can pull this off?
answer: Well... I do have two years of high school drama under my belt. As a matter of fact, I once understudied the Sky Masterson role in a production of Guys and Dolls.

question: Good. That's good, Jack. The thing to do now is stay close to the Cowboy. Wherever he goes tonight, that's * where we're going.
answer: We're not exactly dressed for a night on the town.

question: The Cowboy rides! The Henchman then wheels his serving tray away. Moments later, Jack and Lydia arrive from the opposite direction and approach the elevators.
answer: I love this car. You can't beat German engineering. The Henchmen begin to giggle. Igoe glares at them. There he goes. Follow that cab.

question: Look! Igoe looks again -- sees Jack's Ferrari drive out of the parking garage.
Who do I follow?...
answer: The Ferrari! The Henchman begins to pull away from the curb, when:

question: Which Ferrari??
answer: Huh?! Forget the Ferrari! Follow the cab!

question: Trust me, Lydia. The time will come when I'll tell you everything. But this isn't it. The cab's pulling over!
answer: Jack... Jack leaves the Ferrari in the charge of a Parking Attendant at the curb. He and Lydia shoulder their way through the crowd toward the club entrance. Jack!

question: Wendy...
answer: My God, Jack! Look at you!

question: Howdy, Wendy and Jack. Jack and Wendy sit down.
Say! Looks like we got just the right number for a foursome!
Hurry up!
answer: I'm speeding now! I'm doing fifty!

question: Don't leave her alone in that hotel room with that sleazy cowboy!
answer: Hey -- I don't want them together any more than you do!

question: You don't? Why not?
I knew it! You're in love with her!
You're in love with her!
I... uh... well...
Damn...
I've got your adrenaline pumping! Can you feel it!
You're strong! Very strong! Do you feel strong?
answer: I feel strong! There's his room!

question: What gives people certain physical characteristics?
Think we can tamper with his genes a little?
answer: Sounds like fun, I'll admit. But genetic alteration can only occur before conception.

question: Shit...
answer: Were you thinking permanent or temporary changes?

question: Perfect!
Yup.
How long has it been, Cowboy?
Almost ten years... Both Jack and Lydia look relieved. Don't you remember? Idi Amin's barbecue.
answer: Oh, yes. How could I forget. CANKER * * You haven't forgotten the last time * we saw each other, have you, Cowboy? * Jack smiles uncomfortably. *

question: You look taller, Cowboy. *
Okay! Wait a minute here! Lydia looks perplexed, as well she might considering the situation. Tuck, I want a moment alone!
Shut down your sensors. No sound. No picture.
answer: Bad idea, Jack. I'd be navigating in the dark. And what if I couldn't restore contact? No, Jack. I can't do that.

question: I want a moment alone.
You owe me this, Tuck! It dawns on Lydia that she's in the middle. Silence. Then:
answer: Okay, Jack. Signing off. Tuck cuts out. Jack can feel a change in his body

question: There it is!
Our Pod. Perhaps not as sophisticated as the one inside Mr. Putter, but I think it will get the job done. Jack and Lydia exchange a puzzled glance.

We'll use the chip we have. Mr. Igoe will be placed in our Pod, miniaturized and injected into Mr. Putter. He will then locate their Pod, eliminate its pilot by whatever means necessary, take command of it and retrieve the second chip. Jack and Lydia's expressions darken. * Prepare the miniaturizer!
answer: Where can we stash the girl?

question: Stay right where you are! This is an electronic stun-gun. A nonlethal personal defense weapon deploying a charge of five thousand * vo-- oh, what the hell... ZAP! She fires the gun. Five thousand volts enter the * Henchman's body. He sinks to his knees, but doesn't fall forward. He just kneels there Duane! It's me, Lydia. Listen carefully. I'm being held in a warehouse somewhere along the Embarcadero. You've got to reach Pete Blanchard for me! *
answer: Blanchard?! Hell, I'll call the police!

question: Yes! Call the police. But call Blanchard, too. Tell him we've got Tuck Pendelton!
Pendelton. He'll understand. Tell him we're coming in with Tuck. Dr. Niles has got to get ready for us at Vector-Scope. *
answer: Lydia... are you in as much trouble as you sound?

question: Maybe more. Tell the police to look for the warehouse with the helicopters on the roof.
Thanks, Duane. Lydia hangs up the phone. She glances around the office, spots Canker's lab coat hanging from a hook. She puts it on.
What the hell!? --
Tuck, where are... Oh, no. But... how?
answer: You must have kissed Jack, Lydia.

question: I only... I mean, he kissed me, but...
answer: That's not important. We've got to get that chip. My time is running out.

question: What about Jack?
Ready to inject the Pod into the subject.
answer: Wait a minute. After Igoe takes command of their Pod, how do we get the chip out?

question: Mr. Igoe will pilot the Pod out through a tear duct or sweat gland.
answer: Why chance it? As soon as he takes over the Pod and gets the chip, let's re-enlarge!

question: While it's still inside Mr. Putter!?

Here it comes, Tuck! So saying, he pops the chip into his mouth and swallows it. At the same moment, Lydia comes up behind the Henchman and clubs him over the head with her gun. He once again sinks to his knees.
answer: Let's go! They make a dash for a corridor, SLAMMING a heavy metal DOOR behind them. Where's the chip!?

question: I swallowed it! Lydia winces to herself. Now they realize that they have sealed themselves into a dead-end hallway. But they spot a ladder that leads to a trap door in the ceiling.
Let's go!
Don't worry. Tuck's given me the strength of ten men! I'll handle this.
C'mon, Tuck! Tell me how to fly this thing!
-- not now, Lydia! Tuck, give me instructions!
answer: He can't, Jack! He's not in you anymore! He's in me! Jack looks flabbergasted. It takes him a moment to recover.

question: For how long?...
You mean... when I broke... and when I hit... and when he fell over the thing... it wasn't Tuck who...
answer: It was you, Jack. All you. But we better get this thing in the air.

question: Jack, turn on the master switch. Disengage the clutch, then start the ignition. You've got two sticks at your sides. One for each hand. Here's what they're for... Keep your RPMs in the green, Jack! I've got to reach that microchip before the other guy does. He turns to one of his display monitors. It shows a wire-frame image of Jack's body. Two lights are blinking. One represents the chip, the other represents the Black Pod.
answer: Player Number Two is taking the digestive system.

question: Right. But I can beat him by taking the circulatory system, can't I?
answer: Yes. But that means going through the heart, Player Number One!

question: That was close! How do I find Vector-Scope?
answer: Follow the freeways! I said follow the freeway, not take the freeway!

question: I can't get it back up into the --
Shit! You broke my lucky flask! Afraid of a little electricity, huh! Igoe can't take his eyes off the CRACKLING WIRE. Tuck takes advantage of the distraction and: An android!
answer: The fire is consuming your remaining air! The fire is consuming your remaining air!

question: Where are we now!?
answer: Middle esophagus! Too far to go! Not enough air! Only one chance to make it!

question: What!? Tell me!
answer: A human sneeze has been clocked at over one hundred miles per hour.

question: Lydia, we have to talk in private. Tuck takes her into Niles' office, which is visible to the lab proper through a large glass window. I never got to go up in a space capsule, Lydia. I never got to orbit the Earth or walk on the moon... but I've just gone places where no man has ever gone before. I've done things, and seen things, Lydia, that have opened my eyes. To you... to life... to everything! Lydia looks confused and overwhelmed. Tuck tries to slow down a little. It's not too late for me, Lydia. I can change. I can be better. I'm a different man already... ... I've known all along. Why couldn't I just admit it to myself?
That I'm in love with you, of course. Lydia is bowled over.
You broke my heart that morning you drove off and left me.
answer: You are a changed man, Tuck.

question: Lydia... this is a personal question, but I've got to know. Since that last night we spent together... have you spent a night like that with anyone else?
Please, Lydia. It's important to me. Lydia can see that Tuck means it.
answer: All right, Tuck... No. I haven't.

question: You haven't?
answer: I've been pretty busy, don't forget.

question: We're going to have a baby, you know. Lydia gives him a look. You did know, didn't you?
Be sure, Lydia. I've seen it. Lydia begins to smile.
answer: Is it a boy or a girl?

question: I didn't even notice. We'll just have to wait and see. Lydia wraps her arms around his neck. For a moment they just look into each others eyes. Then they kiss. Jack --
